last_post.content:
In January of 2023 will you publish at least 3 posts to your blog or RSS feed? If so join Bring Back Blogging, an experiment to encourage blogging by listing the bloggers who participate and allowing readers to discover new content.

So far over 130 bloggers joined, including yours truly. I blog regularly, so it was a no brainer.

https://bringback.blog

#blogging #rss

@ink8

I've encountered this kind of pessimism before about Mastodon (kept me from supporting their patreon for a long time.) They recently posted a roadmap; that has given me hope they will focus on ... growing not dominating.

It's tempting to buy-in to the idea that ugly way QTs from other services look on mastodon servers is a conspiracy-- but I don't want to totally jump to that conclusion.

It's better for all of us if this can be ... cooperative.

https://joinmastodon.org/roadmap

title: Cornell University, Cornell Jeb E. Brooks School of Public Policy

last_post.content: A faculty search of potential interest to computational social scientists, at the new Cornell Brooks School of Public Policy: https://academicjobsonline.org/ajo/jobs/23587

Hey, you - yes you, the non-cybersecurity person who’s following me on the ‘Don because of social justice or geekdom or being very bored - have you considered attending or submitting a talk to a local hacker conference?

You don’t have to be a cybersecurity expert or professional to do it. There are often talks on everything from technology ethics to radio hobbies, electronics projects to lock picking and criminal psychology. Hackers encompass a huge and cool nerdy space of hobbies and tangential interests from the philosophical to counter culture. We want to learn about lots of stuff related to why people do intriguing or bad things with technology.

Check out your local or regional community BSides here: http://www.securitybsides.com/w/page/12194156/FrontPage - they’re free or cheap and a lot of fun. You don’t have to be a Mr Robot hacker.

#cybersecurity #hacking

Next was a thorough talk on understanding (old) #Twitter #virality by Filippo Menczer at the #MIT Initiative on the Digital #Economy. This talk gets into the complex interplay between bots, polarization, and #contagion in Twitter #networks. While the days for this kind of research are numbered on current platforms, it's still nice to get insight into how these processes may function. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JAIX0ekFJLQ (6/7)

This is a passion project that I've been wanting to do for a long time...

Neural Story Planning
https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.08718

Historically, partial-order planning was used to generate causally coherent stories/plots. But suffered from knowledge engineering bottlenecks.

Neural story generators struggle with coherence, repetition, and other LM artifacts.

This works updates classical planning algorithms to use an LM to infer actions and causal preconditions

title: Public Domain Day 2023 is Coming: Here's What to Know

last_post.content:
Happy public domain day to all who celebrate!

https://copyrightlately.com/public-domain-day-2023/

@PessoaBrain @introspection @roydanroy

Yes, I have the same intuition as @introspection. But mechanistically it’s an active topic of study. One of the papers I mentioned above (https://transformer-circuits.pub/2022/in-context-learning-and-induction-heads/index.html) suggests “induction heads” as the mechanism underlying this phenomenon: “a circuit whose function is to look back over the sequence for previous instances of the current token (call it A), find the token that came after it last time (call it B), and then predict that the same completion will occur again (e.g. forming the sequence [A][B] … [A] → [B]).”
If the internet runs smoothly, the first entry of @samuelpepys' diary will be sent out by email tonight. Sign up at https://buttondown.email/pepysdiary

title: Millennials are shattering the oldest rule in politics

last_post.content:
Millennials are breaking the rule that people become more conservative as they age.

Leading theory is that experiencing the Great Recession and losing opportunities to build wealth like home ownership have made them more likely to favor taxing the rich.

Since older people have more wealth by virtue of more time to build it, they tend to be more resistant to taxing the rich since it affects them disproportionately. Not anymore.

https://www.ft.com/content/c361e372-769e-45cd-a063-f5c0a7767cf4

So Titan is an Ocean World, has a super-deep subsurface ocean and an icy crust. Maybe like Ganymede or Europa. Maybe even more like Europa in the past, but that's a different story.

There is a model that has a thin crust Titan up to about a billion years ago and things changed. Surface could have looked very different back then.

BUT, unlike other Ocean Worlds, Titan has organics falling out of the sky. Big layer of organics.

This is REALLY IMPORTANT.

Image link: https://photojournal.jpl.nasa.gov/catalog/PIA17240

New paper by Fiona Kazarovytska shows no evidence for memory bias (free recall; recognition) across five experiments in three contexts (Germany, UK, USA). We find no support for (and effects smaller than a pre-defined smalles effect size of interest) for the widespread idea that people selectively remember those historical episodes that flatter their ingroup and selectively forget the ones that put a stain in their cherished identity #openaccess https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022103122001597
